description: Use reported speech to tell what someone said in the past without quoting their exact words.
pattern: reporting verb (say/tell) + that + clause with backshift
examples: Direct: She says, 'I am busy.' → Reported: She says that she is busy.
Direct: He said, 'I like tea.' → Reported: He said that he liked tea.
Direct: They said, 'We will help.' → Reported: They said that they would help.
tips: Backshift tenses when the reporting verb is in the past: present → past, will → would, can → could.
Pronouns and time words often change: this → that, now → then, today → that day.
mistakes: Forgetting to change pronouns (He said I am tired → He said he was tired).
Keeping future 'will' after a past reporting verb (He said he will help → He said he would help).
note: After 'say', use 'to' only with a person: He said to me that...; after 'tell', you must include the person: He told me that...

description: Report yes/no and wh- questions by changing word order and backshifting tenses.
pattern: reporting verb (ask/wonder) + if/whether + clause (for yes/no) OR wh-word + clause
examples: Direct: 'Are you ready?' → He asked if I was ready.
Direct: 'Where do you live?' → She asked where I lived.
Direct: 'Can you help?' → They wondered if I could help.
tips: Drop the question word order; use statement order after the connector.
Use 'if' or 'whether' for yes/no questions; keep the wh-word for wh- questions.
mistakes: Keeping auxiliary inversion (He asked where did I go → He asked where I went).
Using 'if' with wh- questions (She asked if where I lived).
note: Do not use a question mark in reported questions because the sentence is now a statement.

description: Relative clauses add extra information about a noun using who/which/that/where/whose.
examples: The book that I bought is interesting.
She met a doctor who speaks four languages.
I remember the cafe where we first met.
This is the student whose laptop was stolen.
tips: Use 'who' for people, 'which' for things, 'that' for people or things (often in defining clauses).
Commas show non-defining clauses (extra info): My brother, who lives abroad, is visiting.
mistakes: Using 'what' instead of 'that/which' (The book what I bought → that I bought).
Dropping necessary pronouns in defining clauses (The car I bought it was new → The car I bought was new).
note: In defining clauses, you can drop the pronoun if it is the object: The movie (that) I watched was great.

description: Noun clauses act like a noun (subject/object) and often start with 'that', 'if/whether', or wh- words.
examples: I think that it will rain.
She didn’t know if the store was open.
That you arrived early surprised everyone.
tips: 'That' can be omitted in many cases: I believe (that) you’re right.
Use noun clauses after reporting or mental verbs (think, know, guess, hope).
mistakes: Using question order after wh- in noun clauses (I don’t know where is he → where he is).
Forgetting 'if/whether' in yes/no noun clauses (I don’t know it will rain → I don’t know if it will rain).
note: If the noun clause is the subject, keep 'that' to make the sentence clearer: That he passed the exam is great news.

description: Use if-clauses to talk about real or unreal situations and their results.
pattern: If + present, will/can + base (first conditional); If + past, would/could + base (second conditional); If + past perfect, would have + past participle (third conditional).
examples: If it rains, we will stay home. (real future)
If I had more time, I would travel. (unreal present)
If you had called, I would have helped. (unreal past)
tips: First conditional: likely future; second: hypothetical now; third: regret about the past.
Use commas when 'if' comes first: If it rains, we will stay home.
mistakes: Using 'would' in the if-clause (If it would rain → If it rained / If it rains).
Mixing time frames (If I knew, I will tell you → If I know, I will tell you).
note: 'Unless' means 'if not': Unless it rains, we will go out.
